Non-noble metal-catalyzed selective CO hydrogenation of α,β-unsaturated aldehydes to corresponding alcohols is chemically atom economic and practically feasible. This work reports hydrotalcite-derived Co-based catalysts for catalyzing aqueous phase selective hydrogenation reaction of cinnamaldehyde to cinnamyl alcohol. The structure characterizations demonstrate the phase transition from hydrotalcite to co-existed CoOx and metallic Co0 in the optimal Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst. It exhibits superior catalytic activity and selectivity relative to other as-obtained Co catalysts, because of the synergy effect of Co2+ sites to promote the adsorptive activation of CO group and small-size Co0 sites to facilitate the activating dissociation of hydrogen. Furthermore, the catalytic role of water has also been explored. Adopting water as pure solvent and partially adding water into organic solvent can both effectively enhance the activity and selectivity. Such reaction environment may induce creation of more intermolecular hydrogen bonds for promoting the hydrogen transfer and thus boosting the hydrogenation reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Selective hydrogenation Cinnamaldehyde Co-based catalyst Hydrotalcite Water Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Biomass conversion makes a profound impact on the development of renewable energy and chemical industry, and specifically the catalytically selective hydrogenation of biomass molecules represents an important class of processes to product high value-added chemicals [1,2]. Cinnamaldehyde (CALD), as one of representative biomass-derived compounds, can be selectively hydrogenated into unsaturated cinnamyl alcohol (CALA) that is widely used as intermediates in flavorings and pharmaceuticals [3–5]. However, the selective hydrogenation of CALD CO group to form CALA is challenging since it is thermodynamically unfavored relative to the conjugated CC group, as shown in Scheme 1 for illustrating the full hydrogenation reaction network [6–8]. Furthermore, deep hydrogenation also causes the generation of saturated byproducts including hydrocinnamaldehyde (HCALD) and hydrocinnamyl alcohol (HCALA). Platinum group noble metal-based catalysts have been developed to achieve high activity and catalytic selectivity, and nevertheless their high cost limits the industrial application [9–11]. Recently, the development of low-cost non-noble metal-based catalysts (e.g. Ni and Co) has attracted considerable interest [12–15]. In a case of Co-based catalyst, its relatively weaker hydrogen dissociation ability in comparison with Pt-based catalysts leads the hydrogenation reaction to be proceeded at high temperature and high pressure, which usually brings some problems such as energy consumption, environmental safety and unsatisfactory product distribution. Therefore, to further improve performance of Co-based catalysts in heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation reactions needs designing and optimizing the structure of Co-based catalysts. With a given metal catalyst, the reaction medium (i.e., water) has been identified as one key factor to determine the catalytic hydrogenation performance [16–19]. In addition to dispersing the reaction substrate and boosting the mass and heat transfer processes, the roles of the solvent include influencing the catalytic hydrogenation mechanism by regulating adsorption and activation mode of reaction substances and intermediates. As an environmentally friendly reaction medium, water exists in a variety of states, such as solvent water, crystal water or adsorption water, and therefore plays a vital role in the catalytic hydrogenation reactions [20,21]. For instance, the previous studies have demonstrated that the solvent water can polarize CO bonds to enhance the selectivity of unsaturated alcohols, and even participate in aqueous-phase hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of furfural [21,22]. Furthermore, water can also promote the activation of the reactants, assist proton transfer, act as hydrogen or oxygen source, and even catalyze the reaction as a catalyst [23–26]. Water as a solvent not only reduces the energy barrier in the Pt-catalyzed CALD hydrogenation reaction, but also participates as hydrogen-bridge in the hydrogen-exchange hydrogenation process [27–29]. During the spillover of hydrogen species, H-adatoms can transfer their electrons to the d-band of the transition metal surface and acquire proton character, forming interfacial protons and migrating across by the extended hydrogen bond water network [30–33]. Therefore, the catalytic effect of the specific interaction between active metal sites, reactants, intermediate species and solvent molecules would be a crucial issue for metal Co-catalyzed hydrogenation reactions [34,35]. Hydrotalcite (HTs) materials have been reported as catalysts or supports in heterogeneous hydrogenation reactions due to the structural advances of variable chemical composition, flexible microstructures and hydrothermal stability [36–38]. The intermetallic compounds such as CoGa3 and NiZn alloy can be derived from HTs by high-temperature pretreatment, and the catalytic conversion of biomass can be completed by topotactic transformation of catalyst and in-situ evolution of active sites [39]. By adopting this synthesis strategy, the CoAl-contained HTs-derived Co-based catalyst would be prepared with a combination structure of supported metallic Co sites for and partially reduced CoOx sites with oxygen vacancies which may be favorable for the CALD hydrogenation reaction. In this work, a series of Co-based catalysts were prepared through calcination and reduction of Co2Al-HTs as the precursor. The structural evolution from HTs to Co-containing oxide and metal phases was investigated with catalyst characterizations. The structure-activity relationship of the Co catalysts in liquid-phase CALD hydrogenation has been established. Furthermore, the catalytic effect of water as pure solvent and additive in commonly used organic solvent on the hydrogenation performance has also been explored. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Cinnamaldehyde (99 %), cyclohexane (99.7 %), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (99 %), Al(NO3)3·9H2O (>98 %), urea (≥99.5%), Ethanol (95 %), cinnamyl alcohol (98 %), 3-phenylpropionaldehyde (99 %), and 3-Phenylpropanol (99 %) were achieved from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Ethyl acetate (≥99.8 %) and isopropanol (99.9 %) were provided from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Co2Al-HTs material as a precursor was prepared by a hydrothermal method. Briefly, certain amounts of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Al(NO3)3·9H2O and urea were dissolved in 120 mL deionized water, and the mixed solution was stirred for 30 min at room temperature to form a transparent solution. The solution was then transferred to 200 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated in oven at 150 °C for 12 h. The formed solid powders were filtered and washed using excess water and ethanol to obtain pink precipitates. After dried at 70 °C overnight and calcined at 500 °C for 3 h, the hydrotalcite-derived Co2AlO4 oxide was obtained. The Co2AlO4 powder was reduced under 10 vol.% H2/N2 gas at 200, 300, 400 and 500 °C for 3 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min, respectively. The as-prepared catalysts were denoted as Co2Al-H2-T (T represents the reduction temperature from 200 to 500 °C). The structural model of the catalyst is shown in Scheme 2 . 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker AXS D8 focus diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) at 40 kV and 30 mA. The scan range was 10–80° with a step size of 0.4°. The morphology and elemental composition of samples were analyzed using a Gemini 300 field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM). X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) was measured on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha (Al Kα, 1486.6 eV) and the calibrated binding energy at C 1s orbit was 284.8 eV. Ultraviolet–visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV–Vis-DR) was analyzed on a PerkinElmer Lambda 950 instrument equipped with a 150 mm integrating sphere with BaSO4 as the reference. N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms were tested on ASAP 2460 at –196 °C to determine the textural properties of the catalysts. Before measurements, the catalysts were degassed at 300 °C for 10 h. The specific surface area and micropore volume were determined by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and t-Plot curve, respectively. Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was operated on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer with an online mass spectrometer (MS, Hiden QGA). 100 mg catalyst was placed in a U-tube, pretreated at 300 °C for 1 h under Ar gas with a flow rate of 30 mL/min. After cooling to 30 °C, the catalyst was reduced in 10 % H2/Ar from 50 to 900 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The consumption of hydrogen was recorded by the online MS in the entire reduction. Fourier transform infrared spectrum of pyridine adsorption (Py-FT-IR) was acquired on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer. An appropriate amount of catalyst was pressed into wafer, pretreated at 120 °C under N2 for 1 h. After sample was cooled to room temperature, pyridine steam was pulsed into the cell for 30 min, and the desorption signal of pyridine was recorded at different temperatures after the residual pyridine was eliminated. H2-D2 exchange experiments were performed in a fixed-bed reactor equipped with online MS (Hiden QGA). 30 mg catalyst was added to a quartz tube with an inner diameter of 8 mm and pretreated in 20 mL/min N2 at 110 °C for 1 h. When the temperature was cooled down to 50 °C and the MS baseline is stable in N2, a mixture of H2 and D2 with a volume ratio of 1:1 is pulsed into the reactor. The MS signal of H2, D2, HD and N2 gases were recorded in real time. 2.4 Catalytic hydrogenation reaction The CALD hydrogenation reaction was conducted in a high-pressure stainless reactor (NSC50-P5-T3-SS1-SV-R, Anhui Kemi Machinery Technology Co., Ltd.). Typically, 10 mL solvent, 200 μL CALD and an appropriate amount of catalyst were added into the batch reactor. Hydrogen was charged for draining the air inside the reactor. The hydrogenation reaction was maintained at 100 °C with 700 rpm stirring speed for eliminating the mass transfer limitation [40]. The liquid products were measured by a gas chromatography equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and CP-WAX 52 CB column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). The following formulas were used to calculate the conversion of CALD and the selectivity of products. CALD conversion ( % ) = [ n CALD ( initial ) − n CALD ( final ) ] / n CALD ( initial ) × 100 % Product A selectivity ( % ) = [ n Product A ( final ) / Σ product i ( final ) ] × 100 % Where n represents the molar amount of reactant or product; product A and i represent the target product and a certain product, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and morphology characterizations of Co-based catalysts With Co2Al-HTs as a precursor material, the derived Co2AlO4 oxide after calcination in air and the Co2Al-H2-T (T=200, 300, 400, 500) catalysts after further reduction in H2/N2 at different temperatures were synthesized. Their crystalline structure was identified by XRD characterization. As shown in Fig. 1 , the XRD pattern of Co2Al-HTs presents a typical feature of the layered hydrotalcite structure (PDF#97-017-2995) and diffraction peaks are strong, sharp and symmetrical. The diffraction peaks at 11.7, 23.6, 34.7, 39.3 and 46.9° belong to the (003), (006), (012), (015) and (018) plane, respectively. The interlayer space of Co2Al-HTs sample is about 7.5 Å. For other samples after high-temperature treatment, the hydrotalcite-related peaks are disappeared, indicating a complete phase transition from hydrotalcite. The calcinated Co2AlO4 and catalysts of Co2Al-H2-200 and Co2Al-H2-300 exhibit diffraction peaks at 31.2, 36.8, 44.8, 55.8, 59.4 and 65.3°, which belongs to the Co2AlO4 spinel phase (PDF#38-0814). With increasing reduction temperature, the Co2AlO4 peaks become broader in width and weaker in intensity. Co2Al-H2-400 and Co2Al-H2-500 catalysts reduced at relatively high temperatures present different patterns with mixed phases of CoO phase (PDF#075-0533) and metal Co (PDF#015-0816). Co2Al-H2-500 catalyst is insisting of the Co nanoparticles with a larger crystalline size than Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst, since it reveals a sharper and stronger peak of metallic Co at 44.4°. Above result demonstrates the phase transition from CoAl-hydrotalcite to the CoAl-contained composite oxide, CoO-based oxide and metallic Co depending on the thermal pretreatment atmosphere and temperature [41,42]. The morphology and structural feature of Co2Al-H2-T (200, 300, 400, 500) were further investigated via TEM observation in Fig. 2 . These Co2Al-H2-T catalysts show similar average particle sizes at ca. 5–8 nm, according to the statistical results on more than 200 nanoparticles (Figs. 2a, e, i and m). The HR-TEM images illustrate the lattice spacing of 0.24 nm in Co2Al-H2-200 and 0.28 nm in Co2Al-H2-300, which is related to (311) and (202) plane of Co2AlO4, respectively (Figs. 2b–d and 2f–h). New lattice diagrams appear in Co2Al-H2-400 and Co2Al-H2-500 catalysts. For Co2Al-H2-400, the lattice spacing of 0.47 and 0.24 nm is related to (111) plane of Co2AlO4 and (111) plane of CoO, respectively (Figs. 2j–l). The presence of CoO pahse with Co2AlO4 has also been observed in Co2Al-H2-500 owing to the observation of CoO(111) lattice fringe. The increasing reduction temperature causes the phase transition from Co2AlO4 to CoO, which is consistent with the XRD results. The texture properties of the Co2Al-H2-T catalysts are provided by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, as shown in Fig. S1 and summarized in Table S1. Similar specific surface area (SBET) values and average pore diameters are observed on these Co2Al-H2-T catalysts. According to the IUPAC classification, the isotherms of all Co2Al-H2-T catalysts are ascribed into the type IV isotherms with H2 hysteresis loops, which is mainly due to capillary condensation in mesoporous materials [41,43]. The adsorption capacity of N2 increases with the gradual increase of relative pressure P/P0, and then increase the deviation between the adsorption and desorption. In addition, this result also reflects that the Co2Al-H2-T catalysts has mesoporous structure with a relatively narrow pore size distribution, which is line with Fig. S1b. Specifically, the SBET values are 87–114 m2/g and the pore sizes are 7.7–9.1 nm. XPS spectral measurement was performed to reveal the chemical state of C, Al, O and Co species on the Co2Al-H2-T (200, 300, 400, 500) catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the peak fitting results of C 1s orbit show that the binding energy of carbon-containing species on the surface of the catalyst are 284.8, 287.2 and 290.3 eV, respectively, which were ascribed from the C–C, C–O and COOR [44]. The Co 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 spectra in Fig. 3b can be deconvoluted into the peaks corresponding to Co3+ at 780.6–780.2 and 796.3–795.6 eV, Co2+ at 782.4–782.2 and 797.9–797.7 eV, Co0 at 778.4–778.1 and 793.4–793.3 eV, and satellites at 786.5–785.5 and 803.3–802.2 eV [45–47]. The peak position and distribution of Co species are strongly depended on the reduction temperature. As listed in Table S2, the relative ratio of Co2+/Co3+/Co0 is 43.2/54.7/2.1, 65.7/26.4/7.9, 46.8/12.2/41.0, 35.4/15.9/48.7 for Co2Al-H2-200, Co2Al-H2-300, Co2Al-H2-400, and Co2Al-H2-500, respectively. The relative content of high-valence Co3+ gradually decreases and that of metallic Co0 increases as the reduction temperature increases from 300 to 500 °C, reflecting the reductive phase transformation processes from Co2AlO4 to CoO and Co, which agrees with the XRD and TEM observations [41]. The binding energy of Al 2p is about 74.0 eV, and it gradually shifts towards higher energy as the reduction temperature increases in Fig. 3c, while the peak position of Co 2p shifts slightly to the lower bond energy, indicating that with the increasing of reduction temperature, there was strong interaction between metal and support of the catalysts during the H2 reduction process. Depending on the reduction temperature, the peaks of O 1s can be divided into three or four peaks. The peak at 534.9 eV is attributed to the CO bond [48]. The peak at 533.0 eV is ascribed to COH bond and chemisorbed oxygen-containing species (OA) such as CO3 and H2 [48,49]. The lower O peaks at 531.6 and 530.1 eV are ascribed to O2− anion in the oxygen vacancy (Ov) and the lattice oxygen (OL), respectively [50]. Considering that the as-synthesized Co2Al-HTs sample contains abundant interlayer species of CO3 2− anions and H2O, the residual interlayer carbonate species still exist in the Co2Al-H2-200 and Co2Al-H2-300 catalysts after low-temperature reduction [21,51]. When the reduction temperature increases to 400 and 500 °C, the CO3 2− species in the catalyst can be completely decomposed. Therefore, the abundant oxygen species on the surface of the catalyst make the catalyst have a better catalytic environment. H2-TPR profiles reveal the reducibility of the catalyst and the interaction between metal and support, as shown in Fig. 4 . These four catalysts all present a wide and high reduction peak at 400−600 °C belonging to the reduction of CoOx species to metal Co, indicating that these catalysts contain the high concentration of Co2+ species [41,52]. Co2Al-H2-400 and Co2Al-H2-300 catalysts exhibit weak single peaks at 686 and 695 °C, respectively, which are derived from the reduction of CoO species with strong interaction with the support [53]. The reduction peaks at high temperatures of 738 and 804 °C are mainly due to the reduction of the Co2+ in spinel phase [54]. The hydrogen consumption temperatures (i.e., 589 and 804 °C) of Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst are higher than that of other three catalysts, indicating that its support shows a strong anchoring effect on the CoO species. The reduction peak below 200 °C indicates that the high-temperature reduced Co2Al-H2-400 and Co2Al-H2-500 catalysts contain CoO species weakly interacting with the supports [52]. The hydrogen consumption at 243 and 250 °C of Co2Al-H2-200 and Co2Al-H2-300 catalysts are consistent with the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ in the range of dehydrated hydrotalcite. The hydrogen consumption in the temperature range of 310–350 °C is attributed to the reduction of Co3+to Co2+ due to almost no interaction with the support, and the peaks at 350–500 °C is due to the reduction of Co2+ to metallic Co consumes hydrogen [55]. For Co2Al-H2-400 and Co2Al-H2-500 catalysts, the three successive peaks from 200 to 500 °C are absent, indicating that the metal Co0 could be directly generated during the high-temperature reduction, which is line with the XPS spectral results that the proportion of metal Co0 increases from 2.1 % to 48.7 % as the reduction temperature increases from 200 to 500 °C. This result further proves that the ratio of metal Co0 to CoO species on the surface of the CoAl hydrotalcite-derived Co catalysts can be controlled by changing the reduction temperature. The UV–Vis-DR spectra further provide information on the oxidation state and the coordination of cations in all Co2Al-H2-T catalysts, as illustrated in Fig. S2. An absorption band located at ∼657 nm is attributed to the d–d transition of the low-spin octahedron-coordination Co3+ cation. A weak band at 300–400 nm is assigned to the octahedrally coordinated Co3+ species [56]. In addition, the absorption bands at ∼625 and 382 nm are ascribed to octahedral coordinated Co2+ species [29]. It can be verified that Co2+ and Co3+ cations are co-existed in the Co2Al-H2-T catalysts, which is in consistent with above comprehensive characterization results. The Co2+ species as Lewis acid site was further confirmed by FT-IR spectra of pyridine adsorption on Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst. The desorption signal of pyridine was recorded at 300 and 150 °C, respectively. As shown in Fig. 5 , the peaks at 1490 and 1540 cm–1 are attributed to the adsorption of pyridine on the Brønsted acid sites [21,22]. The appearance of Brønsted acid sites could be resulted from the surface hydroxyl groups on the Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst. The bands at 1450, 1490 and 1611 cm–1 are ascribed to the adsorption of pyridine on the Lewis acid sites [22]. In addition, the amount of these two acids on the surface of the catalyst was precisely calculated and listed in Table S3. At 150 and 300 °C, the amount of Lewis acid is 38.44 and 14.47 μmol·g–1, while the amount of Brønsted acid sites is 4.55 and 1.99 μmol·g–1, respectively. Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst contains a large number of surface Lewis acid sites, which is due to the fact that Co2+ has vacant d orbital to receive lone electron pairs from pyridine [16,57]. 3.2 CALD hydrogenation over Co catalysts 3.2.1 Catalytic performance Toward hydrogenation reaction of unsaturated CALD containing conjugate CC and CO bonds, the performance of Co-based catalysts was evaluated under identical conditions. Before the catalytic tests, the mass transfer limitation issue was first considered. With Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst, the effect of catalytic amount on the hydrogenation performance of CALD has been explored, and the results are presented in Fig. S3. In all reactions, the CALA selectivity remains at ca. 73 %. A linear curve of the conversion from ∼20 % to 90 % can be obtained when the catalyst amount range is from 15 to 30 mg. However, when the amount of catalyst was increased to 40 mg, the conversion of CALD increased by only 4 %. Specifically, the conversion of CALD at 35 mg was the same at 30 mg, both of which about 94 %. Based on this result, the optimized amount of catalyst (30 mg) can be used for eliminating the limit by the mass transfer issue in the following catalytic tests. As shown in Fig. 6 a, Co2Al-H2-200 catalyst shows 64 % selectivity to CALA as the CO hydrogenation product but an unsatisfactory activity with 20.6 % CALD conversion. A high CALD conversion at 99.1 % can be achieved on Co2Al-H2-500 catalyst, and however, no CO hydrogenation product, CALA, can be produced. Its selectivity of HCALD and HCALA is found to be 90.0 % and 9.4 %, respectively, indicating that Co2Al-H2-500 catalyst prefers the selective hydrogenation of CALD CC bond. Both Co2Al-H2-300 and Co2Al-H2-400 catalysts exhibit high CALD conversion at ∼97.0 % and relatively high CALA selectivity at ca. 73.6 %. Meanwhile, the CALD conversion and CALA selectivity on Co2Al-H2-450 catalyst are 95.6 % and 39.0 %, respectively. When the reaction temperature increases from 400 to 500 °C, the conversion of CALD cannot change significantly, but the selectivity of CALA gradually decreases. These results imply that the reduction temperature of Co2Al-H2-T (200, 300, 400, 450, 500) catalysts play a vital role in determining the hydrogenation performance of CALD. To distinguish the intrinsic activity between Co2Al-H2-300 and Co2Al-H2-400 catalysts, relatively low CALD conversion level was maintained by regulating the using amount of CALD and catalyst for measuring their catalytically kinetic data. As shown in Fig. 6b, the linear fitting curves suggest that the reaction rate constant of Co2Al-H2-300 and Co2Al-H2-400 is 4.39×10–3 and 5.65×10–3 min–1, respectively. As a contrast, a remarkably lower reaction rate constant at 1.77×10–4 min–1 is obtained on Co2Al-H2-200 catalyst. Furthermore, the catalytic performance of the optimal Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst with time-on-stream was investigated at 100 °C and 2 MPa H2. As shown in Fig. 6c, as the reaction proceeded, CALD was gradually consumed and transformed into the products of CALA, HCALA and HCALD. CALA product shows steady selectivity over 73.1 % within 4 h reaction, highlighting the great ability of the catalyst again the deep hydrogenation of CALA into HCALA. In contrast, the selectivity of HCALD and HCALA remain at lower levels. HCALD selectivity reveals a decline from 18.1 % to 1.8 % while HCALA selectivity exhibits an increase from 10.5 % to 24.9 %, suggesting the facile hydrogenation of CO bond of HCALD. These curves indicate that the adsorptive activation of CO bond of CALD preferentially occurs on the Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst surface. 3.2.2 Discussion on the structure-performance relationship According to the above experimental results, we can conclude that the selectivity of CALA on the Co2Al-H2-300 and Co2Al-H2-400 catalysts is much better than that of CALA in Co2Al-H2-200 and Co2Al-H2-500 catalysts. This is mainly due to the synergistic effect of the oxidized Co2+ species and Co0 in the Co2Al-H2-T catalyst at the reduction temperature of 300 and 400 °C, which maintain a high selectivity for CO bond hydrogenation in the CALD hydrogenation reaction and inhibits the formation of further over-hydrogenation products. The total relative content ratio of Co2+ species and Co0 is positively correlated with the reaction rate constant to analyze the structure-activity relationship in Fig. 6d. Based on the Table S2 and Fig. 6b, as the reduction temperature increases from 200 to 300 °C, the total relative content of Co2+ and Co0 increases from 45.3 % to 73.6 % in Table S2, and the reaction rate constant increased dramatically from 0.18×10–3 to 4.39×10–3 min–1. The reduction temperature continued to increase to 400 °C, and the total relative content of Co2+ and Co0 is 87.8 %, and the reaction rate constant is 5.65×10–3 min–1. This result indicated the Co2+ species and Co0 in the Co2Al-H2-T catalysts have a synergistic effect in the process of CALD hydrogenation. However, a large particle Co0 are generated on the surface of Co2Al-H2-500 catalyst due to the reduction at a higher temperature, and the products are mainly HCALD and HCALA under the same reaction conditions, and the target product CALA is almost not observed, which is originated from preference of CC hydrogenation over the large-size metallic Co sites [58]. Meanwhile, it is not negligible that CALD conversion increases by almost 5 times as the reduction temperature increases to 400 °C, while the CALD conversion remains almost unchanged from 400 to 500 °C. Above result indicated that the metal Co species on the surface of the Co2Al-H2-T catalyst are responsible for the dissociation and activation of H2, and Co2+ species as Lewis acidic site can preferentially adsorb the CO bond, and the hydrogen species dissociated by Co0 spillover near the adsorbed CO bond, which is conducive to the formation of unsaturated alcohol [59–62]. In addition, the oxygen defects produced by the high-temperature reduction of Co2AlO4 and CoO will also tend to adsorb and activate CO bond [63–65]. Therefore, the amount of catalyst, the reduction temperature, the valence state and distribution of the active species on the surface of the catalyst, and the synergistic effect of Co2+ species and Co0 are important factors affecting the activity and selectivity of Co2Al-H2-T catalyzed CALD liquid phase hydrogenation reaction. Based on the high intrinsic activity of the Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst, we further explored the effect of solvent on the performance during the CALD hydrogenation process. 3.2.3 Stability of catalyst The stability test of the Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst was performed at 100 °C, 20 bar H2. At the end of each reaction, the catalyst was thermally filtered, washed with anhydrous alcohol, and dried at 60 °C in a vacuum drying oven for the next performance test. As presented in Fig. 7 , an unexpected stability result was achieved in four-cycle CALD hydrogenation reactions. Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst displays high CALD conversion of 96.2 % and CALA selectivity of 73.3 % in the first cycle. After four run reaction, the CALD conversion is decreased slightly to 88.2 %, and the CALA selectivity is decreased to 65.4 %, which may be due to the weight loss of a small amounts of catalyst during the repeating recycling processes. The spent Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst after the stability test was characterized with XRD, XPS and TEM analyses. In the XRD pattern in Fig. 8 a, the diffraction peaks of Co0 and CoO crystalline phases are retained and the phase structure of catalyst is well-maintained during the four cycles. The XPS spectrum of the spent Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst at Co 2p orbit presents that Co species remain in co-existed Co0, Co2+ and Co3+ states, as shown in Fig. 8b. The area ratio of Co2+/Co3+/Co0 is 29.7/56.9/13.4, In comparison with the fresh catalyst, the spent catalyst shows slightly decreased relative contents of Co0 and Co2+ states, suggesting minor reduction of Co species occurs under the reductive conditions of hydrogenation reaction. As shown in Fig. 8c–d, the TEM image of the spent Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst illustrates that the CoO particles are uniformly dispersed on the surface of the catalyst and their size is estimated as 6.2 ± 1.3 nm, which is slightly smaller than the size of the fresh catalyst. Combined with XPS results, a slight decrease in the catalytic activity during cycling tests might be related to a minor surface Co atom reconstruction with reduced oxidation state which is caused by the weak interaction between metal and support. 3.3 Catalytic effect of water and hydrogen activation Solvents can not only provide a relatively unique chemical environment for the reaction process, but also serve as reactants or hydrogen sources to affect the rate of hydrogenation reactions [26,66–68]. As shown in Fig. 9 a, the effects of solvents with different polarities were investigated on the selective hydrogenation of CALD over Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst. The CALD conversion and CALA selectivity follow trend of cyclohexane (CHX) < ethyl acetate (EA) < isopropanol (Iso-PrOH) < methanol (MeOH) < water (H2O). Considering the solvent polarity order, as summarized in Table S4, cyclohexane (0.1) < ethyl acetate (4.4) ≈ isopropanol (4.3) < methanol (6.6) < water (10.2), the results show that polar solvents can increase the activity of catalysts. According to relevant literature reports, the polar solvent molecules can promote the adsorption and activation process of hydrophilic CO bonds in α,β-unsaturated aldehyde/ketone substances, thereby improving the catalytic hydrogenation activity [69]. The activity of Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst in isopropanol is 2.7 times that in ethyl acetate, and the CALA selectivity is increased by 1.7 times, which may be because isopropanol as common organic solvent to promote the dispersion of products. Although the solubility of H2 in isopropanol is 4 times that of water, higher activity and better CALA selectivity are achieved over Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst with H2O as solvent compared with other commonly used organic solvents, probably because polar solution can accelerate interfacial protons (H+) migrated across the solvent molecular network. Therefore, water as solvent plays an important role in the catalytic hydrogenation process. To further study the catalytic role of water species, the catalytic hydrogenation performance of Co2Al-H2-400 is evaluated by using mixed solvents with varied ration between water and organic solvent. As shown in Fig. 9b, when 1 mL H2O was introduced into the non-polar solvent of cyclohexane, the activity could dramatically increase (by 14 times). The previous work based on the isotope experiments and theoretical calculations have confirmed that the presence of water can reduce the energy barrier for CO hydrogenation and improve the catalytic activity and selectivity of CALA of PtFe and RuSn catalyst systems [27,70]. Addition of H2O remarkably enhances the hydrogenation of CO, which may be due to the strong interactions originated from hydrogen-bond formations of H2O with CO and surface site promoting the preferential adsorption of CO [27–29,71]. The protonation of water-mediated provides an additional hydrogenation channel through hydrogen-bonded water network, reducing the activation energy barrier for CALD hydrogenation. However, there was no regulations to follow in the relationship between water quantity and conversion, possibly due to the uneven reactant system formed by water and cyclohexane. It was reported in the literature that hydrogen bonding interactions between solvent molecules have a significant impact on the hydrogenation reaction of α,β-unsaturated aldehydes/ketones molecules [72,73]. Furthermore, isopropanol as solvent has a high exchange capacity with α,β-unsaturated aldehydes/ketones molecules. Considering that solvent can act as hydrogen-bridges, i.e. can exchange dissociated hydrogen species through a hydrogen bonding network. Thus adjust the amount of mixed solvent of isopropanol and water to control the CALD reaction activity in Fig. 9c. With added 0.2 mL H2O to isopropanol, the activity is increased from 31.4 % to 50.6 %, which may be due to the internal hydrogen bonding between solvents caused by the added water affecting the original hydrogen bonding between solvent and substrate. With the further addition of 0.3 mL H2O, the activity increases to 59.9 %. The activity of the catalyst in 10:90 of H2O:isopropanol is higher than that in 10:90 of H2O:cyclohexane (73.9 % > 65.7 %). One H species dissociated from water or polar alcohols attacks the carbonyl oxygen atom of CALD, whereas no hydrogen species are donated by cyclohexane. These results demonstrate the presence of water its own structural properties may create more intermolecular hydrogen bonds that enhance activity and selectivity [6,22]. Thus, the reaction rate increases with the addition of water in isopropanol, possibly due to the different interaction between CALD or CALA in different polar solvent. The formation of OH bonds through hydrogen-bonding interactions regulated the turnover rate. After introduction of water into the reaction system, the interaction between CALA and Co2Al-400 weakens to a greater extent than the interaction between CALD and the catalyst, which is beneficial to the adsorption of CALD on the catalyst surface and desorption of CALA. CALD more likely forms stable hydrogen bonds with isopropanol (O⋯HOC) than with water, while CALA prefers to bond with water rather than isopropanol because of the stronger hydrogen bonds between CALA and water molecules (OH⋯OH). Overall, the promoting effect of water on the selective hydrogenation of CALD on Co2Al-H2-400 to produce CALA is attributed to the different hydrogen bonding affinities among reactant, intermediate, product molecules and solvent molecules. It further verifies that the water is in a form of a hydrogen bridge to involve in the hydrogen exchange hydrogenation process [27–29]. Based on the above discussions, the possible reaction pathway of CALD hydrogenation over Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst with water as the solvent is presented in Scheme 3 . The dissociation and activation of H2 is an important factor affecting the hydrogenation performance. For example, the coexistence of two sites on the surface of the catalyst has an important influence on the regulation of the selective hydrogenation performance of α,β-unsaturated aldehydes. The metal sites with small particles are responsible for the dissociation and activation of H2, while the oxides in high-valence state are related to the adsorption of reaction substrates. The dissociated hydrogen species spillover into the vicinity of the adsorbed substrate for hydrogenation [21]. In non-precious metal Co-based catalyst, the metal Co is conductive to the dissociation of adsorption of H2 and accelerates the hydrogenation reaction [74,75]. Consequently, H2-D2 exchange operation was performed at 50 °C in a fixed bed reactor with the flow rate ratio of H2, D2 and N2 of 1:1:3, and the exchange rate was calculated depending on the MS signals in Fig. 10 . The Co2Al-H2-T catalyst exhibits good H2 activation ability, and the exchange rate in Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst is about 1.8×10–3 s–1, while the exchange rates over Co2Al-H2-300 and Co2Al-H2-500 are about 1.7×10–3 and 1.4×10–3 s–1, respectively, which is consistent with the trend of reaction rate constant for the catalysts. The main reason is the smaller the particle size of Co0, the stronger the activity ability of H2 [74–75]. However, the exchange rate on the CoAl-H2-200 catalyst is 1.1×10–3 s–1, but the conversion of CALD is only 20.6 %, which is significantly lower than that of other catalysts, indicating that in addition to the dissociation and activation of H2, the adsorption of substrate and the selection of solvent in the catalytic reaction has an important impact on the hydrogenation performance. Moreover, the above experimental results demonstrate that the dissociation and activation of H2 is not the rate-determining step of the selective hydrogenation reaction catalyzed by Co2Al-H2-T catalyst. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have constructed a series of hydrotalcite-derived CoAl-H2-T (200, 300, 400, 500) catalysts by regulating the reduction temperature for selectively catalyzing CALD hydrogenation reaction. The superior catalytic performance is achieved on Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst than other catalysts due to the synergistic effect of Co2+ and Co0 on catalyst surface, as reflected by the positive relationship between the activity and total content of surface Co2+ and Co0 states. The Co2+ species as Lewis acidic sites favors electrophilic CO group adsorption and small particle Co0 promotes hydrogen activation. Meanwhile, large-size Co0 particles tend to undergo CC bond hydrogenation. This work also demonstrates polar water as the solvent strongly affects the hydrogenation reaction rate of CALD and selectivity on the Co catalyst. The small-amount water additive in non-polar cyclohexane solvent can increase the activity by 14 times, because water can accelerate the proton migration and transport in hydrogenation reaction. Furthermore, water-promoted CO hydrogenation has been clarified by using the isopropanol/water mixture solvent, and the intermolecular hydrogen bonding affinity among the reactant, product and solvent has also been discussed. The hydrogenation performance and H2-D2 exchange results are further illustrated the dissociation and activation of H2 is not the rate-determining step in the liquid phase selective hydrogenation of CALD catalyzed by Co2Al-H2-T catalyst. In addition, the Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst exhibits surprised the stability of structural and performance in recycling experiments. coredata.dc:description: Non-noble metal-catalyzed selective CO hydrogenation of α,β-unsaturated aldehydes to corresponding alcohols is chemically atom economic and practically feasible. This work reports hydrotalcite-derived Co-based catalysts for catalyzing aqueous phase selective hydrogenation reaction of cinnamaldehyde to cinnamyl alcohol. The structure characterizations demonstrate the phase transition from hydrotalcite to co-existed CoOx and metallic Co0 in the optimal Co2Al-H2-400 catalyst. It exhibits superior catalytic activity and selectivity relative to other as-obtained Co catalysts, because of the synergy effect of Co2+ sites to promote the adsorptive activation of CO group and small-size Co0 sites to facilitate the activating dissociation of hydrogen. Furthermore, the catalytic role of water has also been explored. Adopting water as pure solvent and partially adding water into organic solvent can both effectively enhance the activity and selectivity. Such reaction environment may induce creation of more intermolecular hydrogen bonds for promoting the hydrogen transfer and thus boosting the hydrogenation reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Water-promoted selective hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde over hydrotalcite-derived Co catalysts
